instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00840: What is 820-00840? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PM_SLP_S5_L: What is PM_SLP_S5_L? PM_SLP_S5_L is a signal that, when 3.3v, turns on power rails that will wake the system from an S5 state. This signal is a part of the power management system of the MacBook.  The \"PM\" prefix typically stands for \"Power Management,\" and the \"SLP\" is for \"Sleep.\" The \"S5\" denotes the specific sleep state, which is Suspend to Disk, and the \"_L\" suffix indicates that this is an active low signal..
definitions.PP5V_S4: What is PP5V_S4? PP5V_S4 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H_CPU: What is PPBUS_G3H_CPU? PPBUS_G3H_CPU is the .
definitions.PCH_INTRUDER_L: What is PCH_INTRUDER_L? PCH_INTRUDER_L is a signal that tells the machine the case has been opened by an intruder when it is low, the _L means it is present when it is low. This signal should always be high in a Macbook since it doesn’t use intrusion detection. .
definitions.RTC_RESET_L: What is RTC_RESET_L? RTC_RESET_L is a reset signal that is present when the signal is low, the _L means it is asserted when the voltage is low. The RESET signal will keep the PCH from turning on or booting up the machine. .
definitions.PCH_SRTCRST_L: What is PCH_SRTCRST_L? PCH_SRTCRST_L is a reset signal present for the RTC circuit that asserts when it is low in voltage, that is what _L means..
definitions.PCH_INTVRMEN:
What is PCH_INTVRMEN? PCH_INTVRMEN is an Internal Voltage Regulator Enable: When pulled high, this signal enables
the internal 1.05 V regulators for the Suspend well in the PCH. This signal must
remain asserted for the VRMs to behave properly (no glitches allowed).
This signal must be pulled-up to VCCRTC on desktop platforms and may
optionally be pulled low on mobile platforms if using an external VR for the
VCCSUS rail.
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.PM_DSW_PWRGD: What is PM_DSW_PWRGD? The "PM_DSW_PWRGD" signal in a MacBook stands for "Deep Sleep Well Power Good” and is required for the machine to power on & post..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: not powering up <SIGNAL>P5VS4_EN</SIGNAL> missing
threads.message:
Originally PP20V was present but no <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H_CPU</SIGNAL>. Replaced <TRANSISTOR>Q7900</TRANSISTOR> which restored <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H_CPU</SIGNAL>, but the board still isn't powering up. Missing <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL> due to <SIGNAL>P5VS4_EN</SIGNAL> being at 0v. <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> is also at 0v. 
Other voltages i noticed was <SIGNAL>PM_EN_P3V3S4</SIGNAL> which is reading 0.024, <SIGNAL>PMIC_EN_P3V3S5</SIGNAL> is present @ 3.3v. 
I've replaced <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> with the same result. 
Any suggestion as to why <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> is 0v or what else to check.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: not powering up <SIGNAL>P5VS4_EN</SIGNAL> missing
threads.message:
Do you get <SIGNAL>3V1_RTC</SIGNAL>?
If yes, check the PCH's RTC signals.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: not powering up <SIGNAL>P5VS4_EN</SIGNAL> missing
threads.message:
Yes to <SIGNAL>PP3V1_RTC</SIGNAL> @ 3.1v
and i'm only seeing one PCH's RTC signal, <SIGNAL>PPDCPRTC_PCH</SIGNAL> @ 1.66. Every other PCH RTC signals are omitted in the schematic and board.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: not powering up <SIGNAL>P5VS4_EN</SIGNAL> missing
threads.message:
RTC signals are not clearly delimited in this schematic, as in older platforms.
But you should be able to catch them, as they have the same names.
<SIGNAL>RTC_RESET_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PCH_SRTCRST_L</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PCH_INTRUDER_L</SIGNAL>.
<SIGNAL>PCH_INTVRMEN</SIGNAL> is not used anymore by this PCH generation.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: not powering up <SIGNAL>P5VS4_EN</SIGNAL> missing
threads.message:
These are all the PCH RTC signals

<SIGNAL>PCH_INTRUDER_L</SIGNAL> - 2.8
<SIGNAL>PCH_SRTCRST_L</SIGNAL> - 3.08
<SIGNAL>RTC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> - 3.08
PP3V3_SUS_PCH_VCCRTCPRIM - 3.3

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: not powering up <SIGNAL>P5VS4_EN</SIGNAL> missing
threads.message:
Do you get <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> (L7690)?
If yes, check <SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: not powering up <SIGNAL>P5VS4_EN</SIGNAL> missing
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: not powering up <SIGNAL>P5VS4_EN</SIGNAL> missing
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: not powering up <SIGNAL>P5VS4_EN</SIGNAL> missing
threads.message: Not much history just that it stopped working. No corrosion or sign of liquid spill or damage. There was a short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H_CPU</SIGNAL> which was resolved by replacing <TRANSISTOR>Q7900</TRANSISTOR>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: not powering up <SIGNAL>P5VS4_EN</SIGNAL> missing
threads.message: Good enough to fry the PCH...
